channel.title: Simple Summing Mixer
channel.description:
I want to sum the output of 2 Axoloti boards I'm using a little mixer right now but I want something more simple.
I don't need vol pots, so I found in the internet and here on the board some suggestions with opamps, but I could'nt find anything that works with single power supply. I need something that works with 12v rather than +x -x.
[quote="jaffasplaffa, post:4, topic:2547"] I was looking at something similar, but since my knowledge about DIYing is fairl limited, so I never got started on it. But I did do some research on making something that several Axoloti could be summed into.
Passive summing mixer: Very simple, doesnt need power, but channels can easily bleed into each other. This is not really an option. I asked a bunch of questions about this type in a DIY group and everyone told me not to build it. So I forgot about it.
I was suggested an active summing mixer:Needs power, but no bleed. mix.png703x253 62.9 KB
From this facebook group:https://www.facebook.com/groups/synthdiy/permalink/10153665170911313/?comment_id=10153665567821313&notif_t=group_comment&notif_id=1462728997773585 [/quote]
Any suggestions?

item.title: Simple Summing Mixer
item.dc:creator: @Blindsmyth Simon
item.description:
@Blindsmyth wrote:

Sure:

ebay.de

Mini Hi-Fi PAM8610 Stereo Amplifier 2X10W Dual Channel D Class Module GY | eBay

Mini Hi-Fi PAM8610 Stereo Amplifier 2X10W Dual Channel D Class Module GY in TV, Video & Audio, TV- & Heim-Audio-Teile, Verstärker-Teile | eBay!

They came in many different sizes/watts. I use this one with a 5v-->12v step up cable on a mobile 5v powerbank.

item.description:
@Blindsmyth wrote:

Yeah got something like this too but with 10W. Makes a lot of sound and hardly uses any battery

71JT5xgqI-L._SL1200_.jpg1200x1200 131 KB

I mean If I could buy a small active summing board I would be more than happy to buy it it's just that I didn't find anything suitable, so I want to try myself.

item.title: Simple Summing Mixer
item.dc:creator: @grit Gritty_Dee
item.description:
@grit wrote:

Of course building stuff is the way to go here, but I've had lots of fun with these 5V PAM8403 boards on the RK003 passive mixer (which is the same circuitry as the 'altoids passive resistor' mixer project on instructables) :

17076367_1752410198406723_6389665654198239232_n.jpg1080x1080

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Summing Mixer
item.dc:creator: @Blindsmyth Simon
item.description:
@Blindsmyth wrote:

Actually with the opamp based circuit I tried I was surprised how good it worked when there was no power (so passive mixing), It summed the outputs pretty well, but it was also like reducing the level on one of them would make the other one louder.

And I want to use simple mixers also to sum different kind of inputs that go into the boards, and also add switches so you can toggle between sending the input to the axos or to the main out.

S for all that stuff learning how to make simple mixer circuits is the way to go I think!

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Summing Mixer
item.dc:creator: @Ersatzplanet James Husted
item.description:
@Ersatzplanet wrote:

You can always make a passive mixer that uses no supply at all. The trouble with uni-polar supplies is either you have to use an inverter circuit to make the negative supply, or live with the fact the mixer won't produce a bi-polar output. There are many passive mixer schematics out there. You can easily make one with just resistors and use the gain control on each Axoloti board itself.

Read full topic

item.description:

No, I ended up not using this circuit. I already had a dual supply, so I took advantage of that. I used something like this:

item.title: Simple Summing Mixer
item.dc:creator: @Blindsmyth Simon
item.description:
@Blindsmyth wrote:

OK thx! So you used this circuit with an opamp?

I've got some lm386n that I've been trying to use for mixer circuit without succes.

9v or 12v shouldn't matter I think, I've even read that more volt gives you more headroom.

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Summing Mixer
item.dc:creator: @Rackabajsarn Daniel Karlsson
item.description:
@Rackabajsarn wrote:

When I was researching for my project, I was gonna build this:

next.gr

Simple audio mixer circuit with fet 2n3819 : Repository

This circuit, a simple mixer circuit. It can mix two signal channels and one channel is output. Using a codec circuit, Convert stereo audio to mono audio time. It can increase the number of channels too. By adding a VR1, R1 and C1 to the amount...

I ended up using an unused op-amp in my mixer instead. But I asked around in an electronics forum, and a guy who seemed to know what he was talking about said he had really good experiences with FET. He also said I could switch the 2N3819 against BF245 or BF256 (I couldn't find that transistor at my usual place). You'll have to look up if you can run those on 12V though, I don't know. Worst case, just pop a regulator in there i guess?

Read full topic

item.title: Simple Summing Mixer
item.dc:creator: @Blindsmyth Simon
item.description:
@Blindsmyth wrote:

I want to sum the output of 2 Axoloti boards I'm using a little mixer right now but I want something more simple.

I don't need vol pots, so I found in the internet and here on the board some suggestions with opamps, but I could'nt find anything that works with single power supply. I need something that works with 12v rather than +x -x.

Using the unused Midi Pins

I was looking at something similar, but since my knowledge about DIYing is fairl limited, so I never got started on it. But I did do some research on making something that several Axoloti could be summed into.

Passive summing mixer: Very simple, doesnt need power, but channels can easily bleed into each other. This is not really an option. I asked a bunch of questions about this type in a DIY group and everyone told me not to build it. So I forgot about it.

I was suggested an active summing mixer:Needs power, but no bleed.
mix.png703x253 62.9 KB

From this facebook group:https://www.facebook.com/groups/synthdiy/permalink/10153665170911313/?comment_id=10153665567821313&notif_t=group_comment&notif_id=1462728997773585

Any suggestions?
